abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome was rated
            unsatisfactory: the project's overall objectives were
            not met even though the specific outputs were all achieved.
            The project's sustainability was also regarded as
            unlikely: on balance the overriding factor was that the
            general political and economic environment did not bode well
            for continuing some of the specific fiscal, regulatory, and
            social sector reforms that had advanced well during the SSAL
            implementation. Nonetheless, under the circumstances, the
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower were
            rated satisfactory. Experiences with this new instrument
            demonstrated the following: The Bank successfully developed
            a "rapid response capability" to help borrowers
            deal quickly and effectively with unexpected, turbulent
            international financial and economic difficulties. The Bank
            could provide an important element of long-term finance when
            it is not available for timely support of urgent reforms.
            These lessons also point out that recent
            "graduates" could still be supported by the Bank
            during an economic crisis--even middle income countries with
            prior access to private capital markets. Although this SSAL
            allowed the Bank to respond flexibly and in an exceptional
            manner to Argentina's 1998 crisis, it raised some
            questions about the new instrument such as assumptions about
            political risk, and the ability to provide liquidity and
            manage grave external finance shortages while enacting
            structural reforms.
